diff.*:
Line 7: Line 7:  
Love can also essentially be defined as the decision to make an unconditional commitment to giving yourself to an other. For the best example of this kind of love, see Shel Silverstein's [[The Giving Tree]]. All the distinctions that many different world cultures have given to the word "love" fall under this definition, as enumerated three paragraphs below. This definition of love is also known to have been watered down into "types" or "categories" because of a perpetual confusion of love with emotion, affection, sexual urges, and, in particular, desire. It may also be due to the immensely painful state of vulnerability and responsibility involved with this decision. (see [[Rilke]]) But essentially, it is a choice, whose truest and purest form emanates from its basis upon what is referred to as intuition, instinct, gut-feeling, or the voice of God.
 
Love can also essentially be defined as the decision to make an unconditional commitment to giving yourself to an other. For the best example of this kind of love, see Shel Silverstein's [[The Giving Tree]]. All the distinctions that many different world cultures have given to the word "love" fall under this definition, as enumerated three paragraphs below. This definition of love is also known to have been watered down into "types" or "categories" because of a perpetual confusion of love with emotion, affection, sexual urges, and, in particular, desire. It may also be due to the immensely painful state of vulnerability and responsibility involved with this decision. (see [[Rilke]]) But essentially, it is a choice, whose truest and purest form emanates from its basis upon what is referred to as intuition, instinct, gut-feeling, or the voice of God.
    −
Love is inherent in all human cultures. It is precisely these cultural differences that make any universal definition of love difficult to establish. See the [[Sapir-Whorf hypothesis]].
+
Love is inherent in all human cultures. It is precisely these cultural differences that make any universal definition of love difficult, but not impossible, to establish. See the [[Sapir-Whorf hypothesis]].
     
Expressions of love may include the love for a [[soul]] or mind, the love of laws and organizations, love for a body, love for nature, love of food, love of money, love for learning, love of power, love of fame, love for the respect of others, et cetera. Different people place varying degrees of importance on the kinds of love they receive. Love is essentially an abstract concept, easier to experience than to explain.
 
Expressions of love may include the love for a [[soul]] or mind, the love of laws and organizations, love for a body, love for nature, love of food, love of money, love for learning, love of power, love of fame, love for the respect of others, et cetera. Different people place varying degrees of importance on the kinds of love they receive. Love is essentially an abstract concept, easier to experience than to explain.
